content.webTitle: Linkorama: the Pentagon mosque, Fareed Zakaria, jobless woes | Richard Adams

fields.headline: Linkorama: the Pentagon mosque, Fareed Zakaria, jobless woes
fields.bodyText: • After the so-called "Ground Zero mosque" controversy, is there a mosque inside the Pentagon? Well, not a mosque as such but an imam drops by every Friday, according to wtop.com: Prior to last Sunday there hadn't been much attention paid to the Muslim services being held inside Room 1E438. They have been going on for the past 8 years. But all that changed last Sunday when Rep Jerrold Nadler, D-NY, who represents the Ground Zero neighborhood, told CNN during a debate over the proposed New York City mosque, that there is a mosque inside the Pentagon. • Commentator Fareed Zakaria takes his leave of Newsweek: The departure of Mr Zakaria, a well-known columnist and television presence, is another blow to Newsweek, which was sold to Sidney Harman, an audio equipment mogul, at the beginning of the month. • The company behind the recall of 380m eggs due to possible salmonella infection has a long record of battles with regulators, reports the Iowa Independent: Owners of the Iowa egg production company that has voluntarily recalled millions of eggs linked to Salmonella outbreaks were significant donors in opposition to a 2008 California ballot measure that restricted cage confinement of poultry. (Bonus for Ayn Rand fans: a company in a place named Galt having problems with the government? Fancy that.) • Jobless claims edge higher, against expectations, provoking another round of fear that the economy's recovery is stalling, a worrying sign says the FT: In the past month, claims for unemployment insurance have been creeping higher and the less volatile four-week average rose 8,000 to 482,500. That was the highest level since December 2009. • Is Sarah Palin's star waning? It appears so, at least in Florida, according to the Florida Times-Union, based on disappointing ticket sales: Slow ticket sales have bumped Sarah Palin's appearance next week in Jacksonville to a smaller venue.... "An Evening of Hope with Sarah Palin" was moved from the 2,936-seat Moran Theatre to the 609-seat Terry Theatre.
